Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Shake Table for Research on Seismic Stability of Rock Masses

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award is for the acquisition of a one-ton capacity shake table to be used predominately for research on the stability of rock boulders and slopes during seismic loading. As evidenced by the large number of structures destroyed and the number of people killed and injured during the Christchurch series of earthquakes, rockfalls and rock slides are serious potential dangers during earthquakes. The shake table will be used to investigate the mechanisms causing rock falls and slides with the objectives of identifying potential hazardous areas and developing methods of mitigating these hazards. Additionally, the shake table will be used for research on methods of isolating structures from seismic ground motion through base isolation techniques.

A one-ton shake table will be acquired. The shake table will be delivered with the equipment to allow 1-D shaking, but could be expanded to allow 2-D shaking in the future. A unique feature, designed to allow data collection involving systems of multiple rock blocks, is a high-speed side-view video camera synched to the machine control system. Historically, a significant volume of shake table research has been done in the fields of structural engineering and structural dynamics, and soil mechanics and (soil) slope stability; much less has been done using rock or rock-like materials, as proposed here. Research activities to be enabled by the shake table include: 1) Response of Blocky Rock Systems to Seismic Loads, 2) Use of Precarious Blocks to Provide Estimates of Historic Shaking, and 3) Development/Testing of Inexpensive Infrastructure Base Isolation Systems, among others. The shake table will significantly enhance the research capabilities of Montana Tech, a primarily undergraduate institution. Use of the shake table will be incorporated into labs in two undergraduate engineering courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation grant allowed Montana Technological University to commission and acquire a custom shake table for geotechnical earthquake engineering experiments, focused on understanding the behavior of blocks of rock subjected to seismic shaking. The shake table was built by Doug Weller of ServoHydraulic Solutions in Boulder, Colorado. It was designed to operate at frequencies from 0 to 40 Hertz, with a maximum payload of 2000 lb. Although at the current time, the shake table is limited to 1-dimensional horizontal motion, the table was constructed such that it can be modified in the future to accommodate 2-dimensional horizontal motion. Image #1 shows the shake table and its components as installed at Montana Tech. Custom software was developed to control the shake table operations, and data are acquired with various instrumentation (specifically Dytran accelerometers) and imagery recorded using a high speed camera. Image #2 shows the software?s graphical user interface and data acquisition graph. The software allows table motion to mimic periodic functions (sine waves of various frequencies and amplitudes) as well as actual pre-recorded earthquake time histories (scaled to a desired maximum acceleration).

Montana Tech graduate student Sara Magallon conducted a variety of experiments to validate and calibrate the movement of the shake table that led to developments to improve its operation and performance. Details are available in her master?s thesis, which is available online via Montana Tech?s Digital Commons. Also described in Magallon?s thesis are the experiments she performed to investigate the toppling behavior of prismatic rectangular blocks subjected to seismic shaking.  Image #3 shows the wooden blocks used in Magallon?s experiments, and image #4 shows the experimental setup.

Acquisition of this high-tech shake table will allow Montana Tech personnel and collaborators to conduct experiments in support of geotechnical earthquake engineering research. Although the original focus was intended to be on experiments to further the understanding of the behavior of rock blocks subjected to seismic shaking, it is anticipated that the shake table will be used for a variety of other experiments spanning the fields of geology, seismology, and civil, geological, and mining engineering.
